all_paragraphs: The worldwide increase in data generation is happening in exponential and distributed ways. Some factors contribute to this scenario such as the evolution of data storage devices, both in storage space and data access speed, and the way this data is stored.

A data integration company named DOMO based in Utah USA conducted a study in 2018 called ‘’ DATA NEVER SLEEPS 6. ‘’ where its main purpose was to answer the following question: How much data do we generate every minute?They concluded that an estimate for 2020 is that 1.7MB of data will be generated per person every second, or 1020MB per minute. Figure1 illustrates the estimated data generated by some companies in 2018.

Both standard statistical methods and/or machine learning algorithms have been developed to analyze rectangular and complete data sets. Typically, the rows of the data matrix represent units, also called cases, example, observation, or subjects depending on the context, and the columns represent variables or features measured for each unit. The entries in the data matrix are nearly always real numbers, either representing the values of essentially continuous variables, such as weight, height and income, or representing categories which may be ordered (level of education, social class) or unordered (sex, marital status).

When some of the entries in the data matrix are not observed, there is a phenomenon called missing data. Some causes of the missing data are, for example, a refusal to answer some questions in a survey, breakdowns in a heat or temperature sensor. There are some strategies for handling missing data, like identify nonrespondents by creating one or more special codes for those entries of the data matrix that are not observed, such as “don’t know” or “refuse to answer”, another way is excluding units that have missing value. This last strategy is very inappropriate because we are usually interested in making inferences about the entire target population, rather than the portion of the target population of some dataset.

When analyzing a dataset for some knowledge not easily noticeable, this data is observed in a tabular format (rectangular or matrix). In this sense, some patterns of missing data can be observed. Schafer and Graham [2002] define that recognizing these absence patterns is an important step in choosing the best technique for filling in these values and categorizing these patterns in general (or random) or specific.

In the absence of general (or random) pattern data, as the classification itself suggests, the absence is dispersed in any record in the dataset. Regarding specific absence patterns, these are divided into two univariate and monotonic subtypes [Schafer and Graham, 2002].

In patterns classified as univariate, there is an absence distribution directed to a single variable when it occurs in item Y but the set of p other items X1 ,…,Xp remains complete. This pattern should also include situations where Y represents a group of completely observed or completely missing items and in short, are restricted to a single data set variable. In monotonic patterns, the absence is observed in more than one variable such that a group of items Y1, …, Yp when ordered, if Yj contains missing values then Yj + 1, …, p will also contain [Schafer and Graham, 2002]. Figure 2 illustrates these concepts.

Another characteristic that should be observed is the mechanism of absence of the data, in other words, what caused the absence. Schafer and Graham [2002] point out that according to the statistical literature it is suggested that mechanism may be a process by which some data is generated and others are lost. Little and Rubin [2019] suggest that the mechanism is related to the process by which data is lost and cites the importance of knowing whether the absence of data is related to the underlying values ​​of the data set variables.

Statistically Little and Rubin [2019] define them as follows: Y being a complete data set and M being the absence set, the absence mechanism is characterized by the conditional distribution of M given Y, f (M | Y, φ) where, φ means unknown parameters.
Rubin [1976] defines three types of display for absence mechanisms: completely random (MCAR — absent completely random), random (MAR — randomly missing), and nonrandom (NMAR — not randomly absent).

Data absence is classified as completely random when its true reason is unknown, and there is no relationship to any other data set attribute (s), ie when M does not depend on the values ​​of Y, so if f (M | Y, φ) = f (M | φ) for all Y, φ, the data absence mechanism is classified as completely random. If missing values ​​depend on any data set attribute (s), it is classified as random. Let Yobs be a complete observed subset of Y, and Ymis an observed subset of missing data, for the absence mechanism to be random, Ymis must be dependent on Yobs, ie if (M | Y, φ) = f (M | Yobs , φ) for every Ymis, φ. There is a third absence mechanism called randomly, in this case, an absence distribution M depends on the missing values ​​represented by Ymis. Graham and Donaldson [1993] define this absence mechanism as inaccessible because it is not measurable and therefore not available for evaluation.

Once analyzed, some actions can be taken to address missing data and ignoring such absences is a possible action, but replacing missing values ​​with actual increase values ​​as a very plausible solution to this problem Rubin [1988]. An upcoming article will be published on this topic.
